One is that there has been inadequate compensation in terms of noise insulation at Kurnell as a result of the flights taking off and landing over that area.

The second is that greater penalties should be in place to take issue with this Thai Airways example. Flights are allowed to take off after 11 o'clock at night—cargo flights and propeller driven aircraft—but it is highly unusual to have this type of breach by a jumbo jet. There seemed to be a fairly cavalier attitude by the spokesman for Thai Airways in response to an approach on this matter. We would certainly be looking forward to discussions with the minister and asking him to see what penalties can be imposed.

talk.start.para: —This morning Australians woke to the news that Australia had bowled out the West Indies for a record low 51 to win the First Test in Trinidad. Congratulations to Steve Waugh for his first Test victory as captain, to Michael Slater on his 12th Test century, to Glen McGrath for his 10-wicket haul and to all our cricketing heroes. Not far from Trinidad, across the water in Florida, a hero of mine passed away—Joseph Paul DiMaggio, the Yankee Clipper, aged 84.

speech.para: DiMaggio was more than just a ballplayer. He was a perfectionist on the diamond, the idol of millions of sports lovers everywhere, particularly those of Italian descent. He is one of the triumvirate of original Italian American heroes. Just as Fiorello La Guardia, who became Mayor of New York City, paved the way for Italians in politics and Frank Sinatra broke the barriers in show business, Joe DiMaggio did it on the diamond. His deeds encouraged many kids from non-Anglo backgrounds to play the game and gave them the confidence to succeed.

Di Maggio came up to the majors in 1936. In 1941, he hit safely in 56 consecutive games, a record that will stand forever, and played 16 seasons in centrefield before retiring in 1951. Most eyewitnesses said they never saw him make a mistake running the bases, which he did with speed, judgment and grace. He won three most valuable player awards, hit 361 homers—with 1,537 RBIs—played in 10 World Series with the New York Yankees and was an automatic selection to the Hall of Fame. The great American novelist, Ernest Hemingway, spoke of him in The Old Man And the Sea:
Have faith in the Yankees, my son. Think of the great DiMaggio.
Simon and Garfunkel were moved to sing about him in Mrs Robinson in that opening line which we all remember:
Where have you gone, Joe DiMaggio, a nation turns its lonely eyes to you.

When he gave the game away, the Yankees retired the No. 5 shirt. He married Marilyn Monroe. Once she met him after a very well attended public appearance and gushed, `You've never heard applause like it, Joe,' to which the quiet DiMaggio replied, `Oh yes I have!'

I am a baseball fan and a Yankees fan, having been drawn to the game and that team by the exploits of their legends—The Babe, Larrupin' Lou, The Mick, Yogi and especially Joe D. I played the game and at one stage dreamed of one day donning the famous pinstripes in the very stadium where Don Bradman shook hands with Babe Ruth. My abilities did not quite match those ambitions but for 10 years I coached juniors in an attempt to help them fulfil their dreams.

Some of them are doing just that today. One of those whom my team regularly played against was Graeme Lloyd, the first Australian to pitch in the World Series—and he did so as a New York Yankee. Australian baseball is on the up. There are six Aussies playing in the majors, with five signing contracts with American major league ballclubs last year alone. All told, over 100 Australian hopefuls have signed. One of the players I helped to coach, Andrew Lineham, has signed with the Houston Astros.

There are two baseball clubs in my electorate of Deakin, the Ringwood Saints and the Blackburn Orioles. This week the Orioles play in the division one final of the VBA. I send Bruce Dicker and the boys my best, and hope they play to their limits and bring home the pennant.

The major league baseball season is a long one, as it was in DiMaggio's day—154 games from April through to late September. One of the American writers stated today that DiMaggio played in an era when baseball unquestionably was a national pastime. DiMaggio performed with an elegance and grace that drew respect bordering on awe. He was far more than one of the best centre fielders of all time; he was one of the greatest athletes of the 20th century.

A sportswriter once asked DiMaggio why he played so hard every day, even in the seemingly meaningless games. He replied that he did so because in the stands there might be a fan seeing him play for the only time. That is an attitude we should all emulate in all our endeavours.

talk.start.para: —Earlier this year a constituent contacted me with a story that I am sure will become more common as the government's contracting out agenda gathers pace in Centrelink. This constituent and his family returned from holidays to find a letter from a Brisbane based debt collection agency stating that it was the first and final notice of a debt. There was no explanation given about how the debt originated and only the merest reference to Centrelink at the top of the letter. The letter came as a pretty nasty shock to my constituent because at no time had he ever received anything from Centrelink advising him of a debt. All the debt collection agency could tell him was that it was an Austudy debt—not how it came about.

speech.para: My constituent then had to make over 10 telephone calls to various sections of Centrelink and to the debt collection agency in Brisbane. Finally a breakthrough. Apparently, on closing its doors and merging into Centrelink, Austudy had sent some of its overpayments to private debt collectors, but without the corresponding file for each debt. My constituent was therefore in the position of having demands made on him by a debt collection agency that could not tell him what the debt related to. I think that most people in that position would do some investigating before handing over the money.

To add insult to injury, my constituent was being charged interest for the six or so months since the debt was raised—the six or so months when Austudy had closed without notifying him of the existence of the debt and the six or so months since the debt collector had taken over the debt. This is a glaring example of the absurdities and inefficiencies of the government's contracting out schemes. Where was the efficiency or the cost saving in any of that scenario, let alone any accountability or service to the client?

There was certainly no efficiency or cost saving for my constituent who spent hours on the telephone trying to sort out the mess. He had no say in whether the debt was to be rounded up by Centrelink or by the private agency but the difference in time wasted and the cost to him is significant. If it had been Centrelink chasing the debt, he would have been saved the run around by dealing directly with the agency that had the information he needed to satisfy himself that the debt was in fact legitimate. Centrelink has quality control measures built into its debt collection procedures—a system of written notification and reminders, information about appeal rights in the event of a queried debt and letters complete with the name and contact details of the relevant officer who has the information relating to the client's debt. Clearly there is no such quality control in private agencies when it can take six months to get the first and final notice.

Ultimately for clients dealing with Centrelink there is recourse to the Ombudsman. According to the Ombudsman's office, the jurisdiction of the Ombudsman over the activities of private parties contracted to perform functions for government agencies is unclear. That is not good enough. This government goes on and on about being in favour of giving people choice. When did my constituent get a choice to have his overpayment handed over to the private sector, thereby forgoing any standards of accountability or recourse?

If the debt was handled by Centrelink, he could have called Centrelink from Rockhampton for the cost of a local call instead of having to call the debt collection agency in Brisbane on a number of occasions. The debt collection agency only has a long distance number, no 1800 number. Remember that this is a man just out of full-time study with a young family that has a budget that I am sure does not stretch to numerous long distance telephone calls.

As to any advantage to Centrelink's operations flowing from this contracting out arrangement, I fail to see them. Whatever the letterhead at the top of the letter of demand says, Centrelink is obviously involved, so people's first reaction is to call Centrelink. Even if clients do not call Centrelink immediately, Centrelink is inevitably going to come into the fray because the debt collector will refer people back to Centrelink for background information relating to the debt. So you have Centrelink staff's limited time and resources spent helping a person whose matter they have supposedly handed over to an outside agency. And you have a private contractor with no ability to give people the information they deserve to know in these circumstances and no accountability for the way they operate.

Meanwhile, Centrelink staff are still held accountable by the public for perceived poor service and Centrelink time and resources are still having to be directed towards a function that was supposedly contracted out in the name of efficiency. This idea of contracting out is used as a justification for cutting the numbers of Centrelink staff, but as this example demonstrates it was the deficiencies of contracting out that caused more work for the Centrelink staff in the first place. Contacting out does not deliver results for Centrelink and it certainly caused my constituent a great deal of unnecessary anxiety.

subdebateinfo.title: Robertson Electorate: Mobile Phone Access, Patonga

talk.start.para: —In the short time I have left tonight I want to raise the concerns of the 300 residents of Patonga in my electorate. Patonga is a village on the banks of the Hawkesbury River. It is situated within sight of the metropolitan area of Sydney, about a 10-minute boat ride from Palm Beach.

speech.para: The people of Patonga do not have any mobile phone access. It is the only town in my electorate that does not have mobile phone access. There is only one road in and out of Patonga. They are surrounded by the national parks in the area and they are cut off on many occasions by bushfires. The people of New South Wales will remember the major bushfires of 1994 when many areas were isolated. Patonga was one of those townships that was isolated, but unlike most other areas they had no phone access whatsoever for the emergency vehicles, the bushfire brigade or the many boats that travelled across from the Hawkesbury River.

I will be speaking with Minister Alston tomorrow. Whilst I realise it is not a direct government decision as to where mobile phone reception is, surely under the service obligations of the carriers something could be done to provide the township of Patonga with mobile phone reception—whether it be Telstra or Vodafone or one of the other carriers. In this day and age, coming up to the year 2000, it is something which most people, certainly those close to the capital cities, expect to have. I will continue to keep lobbying on my constituents' behalf until we manage to secure mobile phone reception for the township of Patonga. Then I will work on their TV reception, which is also very substandard.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 11 November 1998:

question.para: (1) What measures has the Minister's Department undertaken which are categorised as positive discrimination programs, that is, providing preference to certain citizens on the basis of their gender, sexuality, age, race, place of birth or some other personal characteristic.
(2) What are the details and funding commitments involved in each case.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 23 November 1998:

question.para: Did the Minister, his or her predecessor or his or her Department appoint a (a) former member of the Commonwealth Parliament or (b) member of the secretariats of the national offices of the Liberal Party of Australia, National Party of Australia, Australian Labor Party, Australian Democrats or Australian Greens as a (i) statutory appointment, (ii) consultant or (iii) other appointment to government boards or posts between 30 April 1996 and 31 August 1998; if so, in each case, (A) what was the person's name and the position to which he or she was appointed, (B) to which political party was he or she affiliated, (C) what remuneration was involved, (D) was the appointment (I) full-time, (II) part-time or (III) casual, (E) what fees were applicable and (F) with respect to (I) travel allowance, (II) vehicles, (III) telephones and (IV) attendance fees, (aa) what entitlements were claimable, (ab) how often were entitlements claimed and (ac) what sum was paid under each entitlement.

Therefore, records are not collected or maintained by the Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry on the information sought by the honourable member.

Notwithstanding that records are not available to answer the honourable member's question, Mr Bruce Lloyd holds two appointments on portfolio bodies. Mr Lloyd was the Member for Murray, Victoria from 20 March 1971 until 2 March 1996 when he retired, with the Australian Country Party, National Country Party from May 1975, National Party of Australia from October 1982. Details are set out at Attachment 1, copies of which are available from the House of Represenatatives Table Office.

Enclosed for the information of the honourable member, is a list which has been prepared by my Department of all Ministerial appointments made between the period 30 April 1996 to 31 August 1998 (Attachment 2), copies of which are available from the House of Represenatatives Table Office. subdebateinfo.title: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission: Government Scrutiny
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 197)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 24 November 1998:

question.para: What Government scrutiny takes place of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission in the election of board members and the administration of the organisation's accounts.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Immigration and Multicultural Affairs; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: Elections for members of the board of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission are conducted in accordance with the requirements of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act 1989 (the ATSIC Act) and zone election rules made by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs under section 138 of the ATSIC Act. As required by subsection 132(3) of the ATSIC Act, the elections are conducted by the Australian Electoral Commission.

The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission is a Commonwealth authority as defined under the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Act 1997, and is subject to financial audit by the Auditor-General under Section 8 of that Act. The annual audit of the Financial Statements, with the audit opinion published in the annual report, includes a review of the administration of the Commission's finances.

The Commission is also subject to audit by the Office of Evaluation and Audit (OEA), which is set up under Division 9 of the ATSIC Act. OEA has legislative responsibility to evaluate and audit a number of indigenous organisations, including the Commission, and is required to report on all such evaluations and audits to the Minister as well as to the organisation concerned. Results of audits by OEA are taken into account by the Auditor-General when doing his annual audit.

subdebateinfo.title: Badgerys Creek Environmental Impact Statement: Cost
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 210)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 26 November 1998:

question.para: (1) What steps did his Department take as proponent to ensure that the Badgerys Creek environmental impact statement (EIS) provided the Government and public with an objective, cost effective and high quality assessment of the proposed project.
(2) Is he satisfied with the steps taken by his Department.
(3) What did his Department estimate to be the total cost of the EIS.
(4) What was the actual cost.
(5) Did the Government obtain value for money.

(6) Was an extensive list of errors and inadequacies identified during a review of the EIS by reputable observers including the Commonwealth's appointed environmental auditor; if so, will his Department seek financial redress from the consultants who prepared the EIS; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Department sought expressions of interest for consultancy support in the preparation of the EIS for the second airport proposal in newspaper advertisements on 25 and 27 May 1996.

The expressions of interest were examined to identify those consultants best able to prepare the EIS, based on their qualifications, skills and experience in environmental assessment and airport related matters and the firm's experience in the management and co-ordination of major projects.

As a result of this assessment, a number of organisations were invited to submit detailed tenders, based on a tender brief consistent with draft EIS guidelines prepared by the then Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency.

Following a competitive selection process, which was based on a review of submitted proposals and formal interviews, Rust PPK Pty Ltd (now PPK Environment and Infrastructure Pty Ltd) was selected as the preferred tenderer and a contract was signed on 19 September 1996.

Contract management has subsequently been administered fully in accordance with Secretary's Directions for contract management and then Chief Executive Instructions for contract management made pursuant to the Financial Management and Accountability Act, 1996.
(2) Yes.
(3) Budget provision of $15.048 million has been made for EIS studies.
(4) Expenditure to 15 January 1999 was $12.179 million and total expenditure, once the EIS process is completed, is anticipated to approach the allocated budget of $15.048 million.
(5) It is not possible to estimate in monetary terms the value of the EIS process.

(6) No. It is not unusual for a large and complex environmental assessment of a major project to attract a diversity of comments and criticisms. All submissions on the Draft EIS and the comments of the Auditor are being taken into account in the preparation of the Final EIS and, where necessary, further work is being undertaken.

subdebateinfo.title: Badgerys Creek Environmental Impact Statement: Interaction with Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 212)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 26 November 1998:

question.para: (1) Did the Government exclude from consideration of the Badgerys Creek environmental impact statement (EIS) interaction between the proposed second airport and Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport; if so, why.
(2) Would construction of the second airport at Badgerys Creek necessitate (a) tighter integration of aviation operations at both airports or (b) operation of the two airports in unison.

(3) Is it a fact that the operation of the two airports in unison would have a significant impact on areas of Sydney not currently affected by airport operations; if so, (a) was this adequately considered in the EIS process; if not, why not, (b) has the number of residents who would be affected been estimated; if not, why not, and (c) have studies been proposed, commenced or completed to identify the number of residents who would be affected and the degree to which they would be affected.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's questions is as follows:

answer.para: (2) The airspace management for the Sydney region would have to take account of operations from all airports in the region. This situation currently applies in Sydney and in all other cities with more than one airport.

(3) The interaction between the proposed second airport and Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport would depend partly on the alignment of the runways for the second airport. For this reason two runway alignments for the second airport are being considered in the EIS process. Chapter 22 of the Draft EIS includes a discussion of the interaction between the airports and further work on this topic is being undertaken for the Final EIS.

subdebateinfo.title: Badgerys Creek Environmental Impact Statement: Demand Forecasts
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 213)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 26 November 1998:

question.para: (1) What was the basis of the forward aviation demand forecasts used in the Badgerys Creek environmental impact statement (EIS) and who prepared them.
(2) What percentage of international travellers in the forecasts were projected to come from Asia.
(3) Have economic conditions in Asia affected the projections referred to in part (2).
(4) Is his Department using revised aviation demand forecasts; if not, why not; if so, (a) what are they and (b) to what extent do they affect the need for a second Sydney airport.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The air traffic forecasts for Sydney were prepared by the then Department of Transport and Regional Development in consultation with a range of expert agencies including the Federal Airports Corporation, Tourism Forecasting Council, Bureau of Tourism Research, Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics and the airlines. The forecasts were developed using econometric modelling augmented by input from the expert group on factors likely to be relevant to the future levels of air traffic in Sydney.

(2) At the time the forecasts were prepared some 50% of international visitor arrivals to Australia came from Asia. This proportion was expected to increase in the short to medium term. The longer-term forecasts of international passenger movements did not disaggregate by country of origin or market sector.
(3) Yes.

(4) Yes. (a) Revised forecasts will be contained in the final Environmental Impact Statement for the Second Sydney Airport proposal. Although the overall Sydney Basin forecasts have been adjusted downwards, the forecast growth in air traffic is still substantial. (b) The revised forecasts do not obviate the need for additional major airport facilities for the Sydney basin in the first decade of the next century.

subdebateinfo.title: Badgerys Creek Environmental Impact Statement: Cost-Benefit Analysis
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 215)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 26 November 1998:

question.para: (1)Is it usual practice to undertake a cost-benefit analysis as part of an environmental impact study.

(2) Can the purported benefits and environmental and social penalties associated with the proposal to build a second airport at Badgerys Creek be costed to enable cost-benefit analysis; if not, why not.
(3) Would the analysis referred to in part (2) assist decision making associated with an environmental impact statement (EIS); if not, why not.
(4) Is it a fact that a cost benefit analysis was not used in respect of the Badgerys Creek EIS because the quantifiable costs far outweigh the benefits.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The scope of work for the Commonwealth EIS process is defined largely by Guidelines based on the Administrative Procedures under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974. A separate set of Guidelines is issued for each proposal.
(2) A benefit cost analysis on the second airport proposal is being prepared for the Final EIS.
(3) Although the results of the benefit cost analysis are likely to be qualified, they are likely to provide some assistance in the decision making process.

(4) No. A benefit cost analysis was not undertaken for the Draft EIS because of the difficulty of defining the future capacity of Sydney Airport and the complexity of valuing many of the environmental impacts. Work being undertaken for the Final EIS is designed to at least partly overcome these difficulties.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 30 November 1998:

question.para: (1) Did studies undertaken in the 1970s underpin the 1984 site selection environmental impact statement for Sydney's second airport; if so, (a) which studies and (b) have any been updated; if not, why not.
(2) Was distance from the central business district an important criterion in the selection process.
(3) Were sites precluded under the distance criterion; if so, which sites.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Second Sydney Airport Site Selection Program Environmental Impact Statement (EIS), which was completed in 1985, took into account some of the work from past studies into the second Sydney airport issue as well as a number of other previous studies relevant to matters addressed in the EIS. However, as an extensive range of new investigations was undertaken for the EIS, it is not appropriate to suggest that any previous studies underpinned the site selection process.
Substantial further planning and environmental studies in relation to the Badgerys Creek site have been undertaken since 1986 including the current comprehensive environmental assessment process.
(2) Yes.

(3) Sites more than about 80 kilometres radius from the Sydney GPO were specifically not included in the site selection process, with the exception of Goulburn which was included as representative of other outlying sites.

subdebateinfo.title: Badgerys Creek Environmental Impact Statement: Aircraft Noise
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 230)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 30 November 1998:

question.para: (1) Does his Department use ANEF/ANEC methodology to forecast levels of aircraft noise; if so, since when.

(2) Was ANEF/ANEC methodology used in the preparation of the environmental impact statement for the proposed airport at Badgerys Creek; if so, was it the most appropriate and up-to-date methodology to forecast airport noise levels and minimise the impact on residents in and around airports and flight paths.
(3) Does the ANEF/ANEC methodology sufficiently allow for the impact and disturbance caused by noise at night and has it been criticised for this deficiency.
(4) Is it a fact that the USA is discarding the ANEF/ANEC methodology; if so, what methodology does it use to forecast airport noise levels.
(5) Does the use of ANEF/ANEC methodology sufficiently satisfy important social and environmental concerns.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes. The ANEF system has been in use since the early 1980s.

(2) The ANEF was one of the methods used to describe noise exposure patterns in the environmental impact statement for the proposed airport at Badgerys Creek. Noise exposure patterns were also described in other ways including flight path maps, contours showing the number of events per day above 70 Db(A), and indicators showing disturbance to sleep and to learning. This suite of noise indicators provides a very comprehensive approach to describing the expected noise exposure patterns of the proposed airport.
(3) The ANEF includes a particular weighting for night-time noise which was derived from a major study into aircraft noise carried out by the National Acoustic Laboratories.
(4) No. The United States Federal Aviation Administration has for some years used a noise metric called the Ldn for noise contouring. This is derived using a very similar methodology to the ANEF.
(5) The additional noise metrics referred to in (2) were specifically included in the environmental impact statement to address perceived shortcomings with the ANEF.

subdebateinfo.title: Badgerys Creek Environmental Impact Statement: Average Noise
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 231)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 30 November 1998:

question.para: (1) Does the Badgerys Creek environmental impact statement (EIS) base the assessment of noise impacts on average noise levels; if so, why.
(2) Does the averaging technique smooth out peak noise levels.
(3) Has his attention been drawn to international criticism of averaging noise levels to determine noise impacts.
(4) Is it a fact that residents are affected more by peak than by average noise levels.
(5) If the EIS is based on average noise levels, does it understate the noise impacts on residents of western Sydney; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) No. The ANEF system, which was one of the ways used in the EIS to describe noise impacts, is based on averaging noise energy levels. Other ways in which aircraft noise was described in the Draft Environmental Impact Statement (EIS), such as the contours showing the number of events per day above 70 dB(A) and indicators showing disturbance to sleep and to learning, were based on single event noise levels. In addition, tabulated information was included for each Community Assessment Area on the likely range in the number of daily noise events that would be over 60 db(A), 70 db(A) 80 db(A) and 90 db(A).
(2) Yes.
(3) It is recognised that the ANEF system has shortcomings. The EIS has included descriptors based on single event noise levels in order to address this (see (1)).

(4) Studies have indicated that average noise level systems such as the ANEF more closely correlate with community annoyance than descriptors based on peak noise levels. The EIS includes the descriptors based on single event noise levels partly in response to community requests for noise information in this form.
(5) See the answer to (1).

subdebateinfo.title: Badgerys Creek Environmental Impact Statement: Aircraft Noise
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 232)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 30 November 1998:

question.para: (1) Did the Badgerys Creek environmental impact statement (EIS) consider the contribution of airport and aircraft noise to sleep disturbance; if so, how.
(2) Did the EIS canvass international literature on aircraft noise and sleep disturbance; if so, with what conclusion.
(3) Did the EIS identify noise levels at night that cause sleep disturbance, leading to physiological and psychological harm; if so, what levels; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes. The Draft EIS used the Sleep Disturbance Index to assess the likely impacts of the proposed airport options on sleep disturbance.

(2) Yes. The Draft EIS concluded that, of the available analytical techniques, the Sleep Disturbance Index was the most appropriate assessment tool to demonstrate the likely impacts of the proposed airport options on sleep disturbance.
(3) The Draft EIS did not establish a causal link between expected sleep disturbance levels from the proposed airport options and likely physiological and psychological harm.

(4) Submissions on the Draft EIS have raised some concerns in relation to the assessment. All submissions, together with the findings of the Auditor, are being taken into account in the preparation of the Final EIS.

subdebateinfo.title: Badgerys Creek Environmental Impact Statement: Elevated Noise Levels
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 233)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 30 November 1998:

question.para: (1) Did the Commonwealth's environmental auditor criticise the Badgerys Creek environmental impact statement (EIS) on the matter of the potential of elevated noise levels to harm health; if so, did he accept the criticism; if not, why not; if so, what action has he taken to address the criticism.
(2) If the EIS was in error on the potential of elevated noise levels to harm health, who was responsible, his Department or the consultants who prepared the EIS.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The independent auditor has raised a number of issues related to information contained in the Draft EIS.
A response to the issues raised by the independent auditor will be contained in the Final EIS that is currently being prepared.
(2) See answer to (1).

subdebateinfo.title: Badgerys Creek Environmental Impact Statement: Educational Facilities
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 234)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 30 November 1998:

question.para: (1) Does the Badgerys Creek environmental impact statement adequately address the impact of aircraft noise on the education process in educational facilities.
(2) Did the EIS canvass international literature on the impact of aircraft noise on the education process; if not, why not.

(3) Has his attention been drawn to studies indicating that the performance of children learning at school or home is more sensitive to noise impact than most other sectors of the community; if so, were the studies taken into consideration during the preparation of the EIS; if not, why not.
(4) Did the NSW Environment Protection Agency estimate that children in as many as 300 schools in western Sydney could be adversely affected by aircraft noise at a Badgerys Creek airport.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Draft EIS presented a significant amount of information on the likely impact of the proposed airport options on educational facilities.

Submissions on the Draft EIS have raised some concerns in relation to the assessment. All submissions, together with the findings of the Auditor, are being taken into account in the preparation of the Final EIS. Further work is being undertaken where necessary.
(2) Yes.
(3) The Draft EIS took into account the outcomes of a range of studies into the relationship between noise exposure and the educational process.
(4) This question should be directed to the NSW Environment Protection Authority.

subdebateinfo.title: Second Sydney Airport: Aircraft and Ground Vehicle Emissions
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 237)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 30 November 1998:

question.para: (1) Would the development of a second Sydney airport at Badgerys Creek and the associated aircraft and ground vehicle emissions lead to a significant increase in the concentration of oxides of nitrogen in western Sydney's air.
(2) Are oxides of nitrogen known to increase the incidence of respiratory problems such as asthma.
(3) Did the Badgerys Creek environmental impact statement allow for increased concentration of oxides of nitrogen; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The extent of any increases in the concentration of oxides of nitrogen in western Sydney's air due to the development of a major airport at Badgerys Creek was addressed in the Draft EIS and further work on this topic is being undertaken for the Final EIS.

(2) The Draft EIS indicates that health impacts associated with increases in nitrogen oxide concentrations are difficult to assess because available data does not allow quantification of changes in lung function at levels below 30 parts per 100 million.
(3) Yes, see answer to (1) above.

subdebateinfo.title: Badgerys Creek Environmental Impact Statement: Surface and Ground Water
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 273)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 2 December 1998:

question.para: (1) Does the construction of an airport have significant impact upon the site's surface and ground water.
(2) Did the Badgerys Creek environmental impact statement present an assessment of the impact of the proposed airport on regional flooding, creek stability and surface water quality; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The construction of an airport does not necessarily have a significant impact on surface and ground water quality. I am advised that the quality of surface water discharged from the site can be controlled by providing safeguards and implementing procedures to prevent contaminants entering the drainage system. Similarly, properly engineered surface water drainage facilities, and fuel storage and delivery systems would protect the ground water system from obvious sources of pollution.

(2) A wide range of surface and ground water issues was analysed in the Draft Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) for the second airport proposal. In response to the auditor's report and public comments, further work on a number of water quality issues is being undertaken for the Final EIS.

subdebateinfo.title: Second Sydney Airport: Hawkesbury/Nepean River System
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 274)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 2 December 1998:

question.para: (1) Did his Department commission a report, before the environmental impact statement (EIS) was commissioned, on the impact of an airport at Badgerys Creek on the Hawkesbury/Nepean river system; if so, (a) when was the report received, (b) who prepared it, (c) what did it cost, (d) did it conclude that the Hawkesbury/Nepean river system is known to be subject to significant pollution burdens from existing sources in western Sydney, including sources in the Badgerys Creek area and (e) did his Department insist that the report be used for the EIS; if not, why not.
(2) Did the EIS conclude that the proposed airport would have significant impacts on the Hawkesbury/Nepean river system; if so, why.
(3) Has the Department reconciled two completely different approaches to assessing impact on the river system; if so, how.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) No. However, the then Department of Transport was a member of the joint Commonwealth, State and Local Government Task Force on Planning for the Sub-Region Surrounding Sydney West Airport which commissioned consultants to prepare a water cycle management plan for possible future urban development in the Sydney West Airport Sub-region.
(a) The Department received a copy of the Draft Final Report in November 1995.
(b) SMEC Australia Pty Ltd.
(c) The then Department of Transport did not contribute financially to this study.

(d) One of the conclusions of the study was that water quality was unacceptable throughout the study area, but the most severe problem occurred downstream of the sewerage treatment plants along South Creek due to sewage effluent. A primary objective of the study was to prepare an integrated water cycle management system which would enhance the performance and water quality of the sub-catchments within the sub-region, in the light of potential urban development.

(e) No. The study was based on a number of urban development scenarios for the Sydney West Airport Sub-Region which were not consistent with land use planning assumptions used in the Draft EIS. Furthermore, it is outside the scope of the EIS to examine water quality implications of potential future urban development around the proposed airport.

(2) The Draft EIS found that there would be moderate local and regional impacts from effluent discharges, particularly from nutrient additions. In response to concerns raised in public submissions on the Draft EIS, further studies on water management for the proposed airport have been undertaken and will be published in the Final EIS.
(3) See (1)(e) above.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 2 December 1998:

question.para: Did his Department engage a team of consultants to consider the Aboriginal cultural heritage of the proposed airport site at Badgerys Creek; if so, did the team include an appropriately qualified heritage practitioner; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: Yes. Details of the team members and their qualifications are included in the EIS documents.

subdebateinfo.title: Second Sydney Airport: Aboriginal Sites and Relics
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 284)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 2 December 1998:

question.para: If the Badgerys Creek airport proposal proceeds, will the Commonwealth act consistently with NSW legislation in relation to the removal or disturbance of Aboriginal sites or relics encountered during the airport's construction.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: It is not possible at this stage to specify the arrangements under which an airport would be developed at Badgerys Creek.

subdebateinfo.title: Badgerys Creek Environmental Impact Statement: Wider Impacts
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 285)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 2 December 1998:

question.para: Is it a fact that the impacts of the proposed airport at Badgerys Creek will extend well beyond the nominal airport boundaries; if so, has the environmental impact statement avoided considering the wider impacts; if so, why.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: The impacts of the proposed airport at Badgerys Creek would extend well beyond the nominal airport boundaries. The Draft Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) includes a detailed assessment of impacts such as aircraft noise, air quality and surface traffic which are clearly not confined to the airport site. While the Draft EIS also contains substantial information on the extent of supporting off-site infrastructure such as road and rail links, the detailed environmental assessment of such infrastructure is outside the scope of this EIS and would need to be undertaken separately under relevant New South Wales environmental legislation.

subdebateinfo.title: Badgerys Creek Environmental Impact Statement: Costings
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 286)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 2 December 1998:

question.para: Does the Badgerys Creek environmental impact statement present costings for the management, mitigation and monitoring of the impacts of the proposed airport development; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: The Draft Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) does present separate costings for the management and mitigation of impacts associated with aircraft noise. Furthermore, provision for management, mitigation and monitoring of impacts associated with the on-site construction of the airport has been made in the airport development costs presented in the Draft EIS.

While a range of environmental management measures are being considered in the EIS process, it is not the role of the EIS to make specific commitments to any particular measures. The extent of such commitments and the relative responsibility for their implementation are matters that will need to be considered by the Government. talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 9 December 1998:

question.para: Has the Government assessed the implications for migration to Australia from New Zealand following changes to immigration policy recently announced by the New Zealand Government; if so, what are the results of the assessment, especially with respect to New Zealand initiatives on business, investment and skilled migration.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Immigration and Multicultural Affairs; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: The Government has examined the implications of the recent changes to New Zealand immigration requirements and their possible impact on migration to Australia from New Zealand.

The changes announced by the New Zealand Government are intended to facilitate migration under the business, investment and skilled visa categories. The measures appear to be largely a response to the difficulty New Zealand is facing in achieving its annual immigration target.
Many of the changes will more closely align Australian and New Zealand policies on skilled and business migration:
. the new long-term temporary business visa has strong similarities in terms of benefits, policy criteria and intent to Australia's temporary business entry (long stay) Independent Executive visa;

. New Zealand's new Entrepreneur visa category mirrors Australia's Established Business in Australia category. Both visas give permanent residence to persons who have established successful businesses in the respective countries and are linked to temporary visa options—either the long term business visa (New Zealand) or the Independent Executive visa (Australia).

. Revisions to New Zealand's Investor visa will more closely align it with Australia's Investment Linked subclasses. Both visas focus on skills and business acumen rather than wealth and require applicants to demonstrate their commitment by investing substantial sums.

. New Zealand's points-tested General Skills category is broadly similar to Australia's Independent and Skilled-Australian Linked (SAL) categories. A number of the new measures replicate changes to the Independent and SAL categories announced in August 1998. These measures include preference being given within the points test to applicants with qualifications gained in New Zealand and increased flexibility in the assessment of work experience.

Despite these moves towards similar visa structures, Australia's business migration visas include pathways and choices not catered for by the New Zealand model, such as visa options for experienced business owners and senior executives who wish to go into business in Australia.

Under the Trans-Tasman Travel Agreement, Australian and New Zealand citizens may enter each others' countries to visit, live and work. It is unlikely that the announced changes will have a significant impact on the level of migration from New Zealand to Australia. The number of New Zealand citizens migrating to Australia in any one year depends largely on Australian economic conditions compared with those prevailing in New Zealand rather than on New Zealand's migration policies. The changes do not, in any case, involve an increase in New Zealand's overall immigration level but are simply policy measures to assist in meeting existing targets.

Data on settler arrivals indicates that migration to New Zealand is not being used to any significant extent as an avenue for eventual migration to Australia. In 1997-98, 24.3% of the 19,393 New Zealand settlers arriving in Australia were born in a third country. This proportion has not changed significantly in the past five years. It is also noted that, contrary to claims by some groups, only 5.8% of New Zealand citizens settling in Australia in 1997-98 were born in Asia. Migrants from this region fill the bulk of places in New Zealand's skilled and business migrant intake.

New Zealand citizens who migrate to Australia have a reasonably good labour market record and hence have a positive impact on the economy and budget. This positive budgetary impact will be further enhanced once legislation to further extend the two year wait for access to social security benefits to New Zealand citizen arrivals is in place.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 11 February 1999:

question.para: (1) When was the State/Territory Nominated Independent Migration Scheme established and what were its precursors.
(2) How were the numbers of skilled migrants each State and Territory could nominate established.
(3) Were State and Territory Governments consulted before the numbers were allocated; if so, when were they consulted; if not, why were they not consulted.
(4) What other individuals or organisations were consulted in each State and Territory before the numbers were allocated.
(5) How many skilled migrants could each State and Territory nominate in each year of operation of the scheme.
(6) How many skilled migrants were actually recruited under this scheme for each State and Territory in each year of operation of this scheme.
(7) From which countries did skilled migrants come and what skills did each individual have to allow them to be recruited under this scheme.
(8) Was the level of English language competence tested for each person who successfully came to Australia under the scheme.

(9) Have persons recruited under the scheme had prior association with Australia such as other members of the family already being in Australia or the ownership of property or other investments in Australia.
(10) How many persons recruited under the scheme settled in non-metropolitan Australia.
(11) What was the policy basis for the establishment of this scheme to replace any precursor scheme.
(12) Will the scheme be independently assessed for its social and economic value to Australia; if so, when.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Immigration and Multicultural Affairs; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Regulations to establish the State Territory Nominated Independent (STNI) scheme came into effect on 1 November 1997. It did not have any precursors.

(2) The Regulations provide that the Minister can gazette a specified number of nominations under the scheme for a given financial year for each State or Territory. The relevant regulation [135.222(3)] reads as follows:

The Minister must not accept a nomination if its acceptance would result in the number of Subclass 135 visa nominations made in a financial year, for a State or Territory, exceeding the maximum number of Subclass 135 visa nominations, as determined by Gazette Notice, that may be accepted, for the State or Territory, in that financial year.

No Gazette notice has been made under this Regulation to date. A notional figure of 200 primary applicants per State/Territory per program year emerged from discussions with State/Territory governments on the scheme. This notional figure has not been reached in any one year by any State or Territory. To date only the South Australian Government has actually used the scheme. Other State/Territory governments have indicated that they will monitor South Australia's experience before making any commitment to participate.

(3) A recommendation to establish a scheme of this nature was contained in the report of the Commonwealth State Working Party on Regional Migration which was presented to Ministers in December 1996. State and Territory Ministers endorsed the concept at the Ministerial Council meeting in Darwin on 14 March 1997. State and Territory Government officials were subsequently consulted at several stages in the development of the Regulations.
There continues to be ongoing consultation on the scheme via the existing Commonwealth/State Working Party on Long Term Options for Skilled Migration.
Individual nominations by South Australia are made by the South Australian Government in consultation with the Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business (DEWRSB).

(4) It was open to State and Territory Governments to consult with other bodies and agencies within their jurisdiction as part of the consultative process. The Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (DIMA) consulted with relevant Commonwealth agencies, notably the former Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (DEETYA). Consultations on the scheme continue with DEWRSB.

(5) No Gazette Notice has been made limiting nominations under the scheme. If the notional allocation of 200 primary applicants is reached, it is open to the relevant State/Territory Government to negotiate a higher figure. I have indicated on a number of occasions that room would be found within the Migration Program if demand under the scheme was to increase.

(6) In 1997-98 no visas were granted under the scheme although the first nominations were processed towards the end of 1997-98 (some 6 months after the scheme came into effect). During this 6 month period there were extensive consultations between agencies in the South Australian Government and DIMA and the former DEETYA on the detailed operation of the scheme. In 1998-99 some 132 visas were granted to the end of January 1999 of which 37 were to primary applicants and the remainder to dependents.
(7) The country of origin breakdown for the primary applicants granted visas under the scheme was as follows:
* It should be noted that country of birth does not necessarily correspond to the country where visa was issued.
The skill breakdown by occupational group for primary applicants was as follows:
(8) Yes—all applicants who are recorded in the Skill Matching Database, which is the source for all nominations under the scheme, have had their English language proficiency assessed.
(9) Persons nominated under the scheme may have had previous associations with Australia but this is not a requirement of the scheme and is not tested in the regulations. The core requirements are:
. that they meet prescribed skill, English language and age criteria; and
. that they are nominated by a State or Territory government on the basis of the fact that they have an occupation which is deemed by the nominating government to be in shortage in that jurisdiction
(10) This is not known. The South Australian Government is keen to attract more skilled migrants to the State as a whole and it makes use of the scheme in that context.

(11) There was no precursor scheme. The policy basis of the scheme was to create a State/Territory government driven mechanism that would enable a higher degree of targeting of Independent migrants to State specific skill shortages.

(12) One barometer of the scheme's success will be the feedback from the jurisdictions using the scheme. Feedback to date from South Australia has been highly positive. My Department is also considering the practicability of setting up (in cooperation with participating State governments) a longer term monitoring strategy, which might include some form of longitudinal survey.
